conclusion: Shadows are formed when an object blocks the path of light, and their shape and size depend on the relative positions of the light source, the object, and the surface receiving the shadow.
There are four objects: an apple, a piece of paper, a glass bowl, and a chicken drumstick, each casting distinct shadows labeled A, B, C, and D on the ground.
Initially, the light source is positioned such that it creates distinct shadows on the ground.
When the light source moves upward, the angle at which the light hits the objects becomes less steep, making the light rays more parallel to the vertical axis.
When the light source moves upward, the distance between the light source and the objects increases.

As the light source moves upward, the shadows will move closer to the objects that cast them because the light rays become more perpendicular to the ground, reducing the lateral displacement of the shadows.
As the light source moves upward, the shadows will become smaller because the light rays hit the objects from a more top-down perspective, reducing the elongation effect.
Shadow A (Apple) moves closer to the apple and becomes smaller.
Shadow B (Paper) moves closer to the paper and becomes smaller.
Shadow C (Glass Bowl) moves closer to the glass bowl and becomes smaller.
Shadow D (Chicken Drumstick) moves closer to the chicken drumstick and becomes smaller.
When the light source moves upward, the shadows A, B, C, and D will all move closer to their respective objects and decrease in size.
